title: Integrating Large Language Models in Political Discourse Studies on Social Media: Challenges of Validating an LLMs-in-the-loop Pipeline | Sociologica
snippet: This article mentions Fabio Giglietto as an Associate Professor of Internet Studies at the University of Urbino Carlo Bo. It also mentions his research interests, which include the relationship between information theory, media, and digital technologies, and their impact on society, as well as his use of computational methods to analyze online information dissemination and media manipulation.
description: The article 'Integrating Large Language Models in Political Discourse Studies on Social Media' mentions Fabio Giglietto as an Associate Professor of Internet Studies at the University of Urbino Carlo Bo, and relates to his research interests in the impact of digital technologies on society and computational methods for analyzing online information.

title: Meta Is Getting Rid of CrowdTangle — and Its Replacement Isn't As Transparent or Accessible - Proof News
snippet: This article quotes Fabio Giglietto, an associate professor of internet studies at the University of Urbino, regarding Meta's MCL. He discusses the limitations of the MCL compared to CrowdTangle, particularly regarding data exporting restrictions, which impacts his work on the Vera AI EU disinformation research project.
description: The article discusses Meta's replacement of CrowdTangle with MCL and quotes Fabio Giglietto, an associate professor of internet studies at the University of Urbino, regarding the limitations of the MCL, especially its impact on his disinformation research within the Vera AI EU project.

Il Premio Rimini Mundi a sette ambasciatori del congressuale - lapiazzarimini.it
Cracking the code: social data access and the DSA's impact on disinformation research
snippet: This article, part of the PROMPT series, is co-authored by Massimo Terenzi and Fabio Giglietto. It discusses the impact of the Digital Services Act (DSA) on social media research, particularly in the context of disinformation. It highlights both the opportunities and limitations of the DSA in providing researchers with access to platform data.
description: This article, co-authored by Fabio Giglietto, explores the implications of the Digital Services Act on social media research and disinformation studies, examining both opportunities and limitations for researchers.
